articles.title: Canberra drone show start time moved later to accommodate threatened species
articles.summary: This year's Australia Day drone shows over Canberra's Lake Burley Griffin have been delayed to accommodate a colony of grey-headed flying foxes in Commonwealth Park. ACT Wildlife has warned a significant number of drones in their path could be dangerous. The first show of the evening was delayed at the last minute from its scheduled 8:30 pm start to 9:00 pm due to the presence of the bats.

articles.title: Last year was the hottest year in recorded history. Buckle up.
articles.author: Eric Holthaus
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year in recorded history. Global temperatures crossed the 1.5 degrees Celsius mark that the world agreed to not cross 10 years ago in Paris. An analysis of the path the world is currently on shows that we're headed for somewhere between 2.2 and 3.4 degrees of warming.

articles.title: Area school closures, delays for Friday, Jan. 24
articles.author: Cumberland Times-News
articles.summary: Mineral County Schools has announced a two-hour delay for Friday, Jan. 24, 2025, due to inclement weather. Hampshire County Schools have also announced a delay for the same day due to bad weather.      Â

articles.title: Homeschooling registrations skyrocketing across Australia
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Homeschooling registrations are skyrocketing across Australia. Changing attitudes around education and family lifestyles are some of the reasons why homeschooling is on the rise.    i.e. changing attitudes about education, family lifestyles and changing lifestyles.

articles.title: International flight disruptions as workers strike
articles.author: Emily Verdouw
articles.summary: International flights at major Australian airports are facing delays as more than 1000 ground workers stage a four-hour strike. Ground workers are protesting poor pay, insecure working conditions and the lingering impacts of Qantas outsourcing practices at the major airports. The strike is due to last for four hours.

articles.title: Another eerie pattern is emerging in the Antarctic
articles.author: Ariana Bindman
articles.summary: There was an all-time record-breaking melting of the Amery Ice Shelf on Dec. 25 and 26. NASA satellite technology captured surreal images of blue meltwater ponds along the third largest ice shelf in Antarctica. The Amery is 300 miles long and fed by several massive glaciers that converge near the continent's edge. Global warming is causing more surface melt in the region.

articles.title: Gulf of Whatnow? Trump's geographic renaming plans leave mapmakers pondering what to do next
articles.author: Laurie Kellman
articles.summary: Mapmakers and teachers are re-thinking what to call the Gulf of America after President Trump ordered it renamed from Gulf of Mexico to "Gulf of America" because of Donald Trump's orders. It is a gulf of water between Mexico, the United States and Cuba.

articles.title: A23a iceberg threatens South Georgia wildlife
articles.author: Farah Mokrani
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, A23a, is heading toward South Georgia. It calved off the Filchner Ice Shelf in Antarctica way back in 1986. It got stuck on the seabed for a while before breaking free in December and is now drifting northwards towards South Georgia, which is 173 miles (280 km) away. It's one of the oldest icebergs ever recorded, and it's a fair size, even after shrinking a bit. It originally measured 3,900 sq km, but recent images show it's now down to around 3,500 sq km – still about the size of Cornwall.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on collision course with British island
articles.author: Samuel Montgomery
articles.summary: The world's largest and oldest iceberg is on a collision course with a British island. The mega-iceberg, known as A23a, is twice the size of Greater London. It broke off the Filchner Ice Shelf in Antarctica in 1986 and ran aground for 30 years. It became dislodged from the seafloor in 2020 and began drifting northwards until it was trapped in a swirling ocean vortex in 2024. It has now been slingshotted in the direction of the British overseas territory of South Georgia 278 kilometres away.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on collision course with British island
articles.author: Samuel Montgomery
articles.summary: A23a, the world's largest and oldest iceberg is on a collision course with a British island. It broke off the Filchner Ice Shelf in Antarctica in 1986 and ran aground for 30 years. It became dislodged from the seafloor in 2020 and began drifting northwards until it was trapped in a swirling ocean vortex in 2024. It has now been slingshotted in the direction of the British overseas territory of South Georgia.

articles.title: Forecasters already looking ahead to 2025 hurricane season
articles.author: Andrew Shipley
articles.summary: Forecasters are already preparing the forecast for the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season. Dr. Phil Klotzbach is a senior research scientist at Colorado State University. The current La Niña in the Pacific is reducing wind shear in the Atlantic. La Niñas are becoming more the norm on a warming planet.

articles.title: Annapolis Launches Maritime Resilience Initiative to Combat Climate Challenges
articles.author: Eoa Staff
articles.summary: The newly launched Annapolis Maritime Resilience Initiative (AMRI) aims to tackle environmental and infrastructural issues head-on. The initiative seeks to develop comprehensive solutions to mitigate the impacts of climate change on local infrastructure, neighborhoods, and the natural environment. Residents and stakeholders are encouraged to contribute their insights and experiences at an upcoming community meeting on February 4, 2025.

articles.title: Restricted fire season declared for inland Buller, Grey districts
articles.summary: A restricted fire season has been declared for the Grey and Buller inland areas on the West Coast until further notice. Anyone who wants to light an outdoor fire will need a permit. There will be some rain over the next couple of days, but it won't be enough to stop the spread of wildfires.

articles.title: Southwest Florida Water Management District faces hurricane debris, damage
articles.author: The News Service
articles.summary: The Southwest Florida Water Management District next week could free up $4.34 million to clear debris and repair damage caused by the three hurricanes that hit the state in 2024. Florida was hit in 2024 by hurricanes Debby, Helene and Milton. The 2025 hurricane season will start on June 1.

articles.title: Winter is the fastest warming season across Springfield area
articles.author: Adam Strzempko
articles.summary: Winter is the fastest warming season for 76 percent of 245 locations according to Climate Central. From 1970 to 2024 winters have warmed more than 5 degrees in the Springfield area. Warmer winters mean earlier snow melts, longer allergy seasons, and more challenges for farmers.

articles.title: CACC to close all campuses Jan. 24 due to ice presence on roads
articles.author: Andrew Garner
articles.summary: Coastal Alabama Community College will close all campuses on January 24, 2025 due to continued ice presence on the roads, due to the continued ice on roads, and will be closed on Friday, January 24. 2025.    Trinity Audio Player is ready.

articles.title: Demand to expedite flood protection measures along Beas to safeguard vulnerable areas
articles.author: Dipender Manta
articles.summary: Anup Thakur, president of Kullu-Manali Paryatan Vikas Mandal, has appealed to Chief Minister Sukhvinder Singh Sukhu to expedite flood protection measures along the Beas river. Heavy devastation was caused by flash floods in 2023. The flash floods severely impacted the Chandigarh-Manli highway, which runs parallel to the river and is vital for tourism.

articles.title: ICCEP-GHANA commends President Mahama's decision on climate change leadership
articles.author: Modern Ghana
articles.summary: The Institute of Coastal Climate and Environmental Protection congratulates the President of Ghana on the appointment of a Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. ICCEP-GHANA is a research and advocacy organization dedicated to promoting sustainable development and environmental stewardship in Ghana. They look forward to collaborating with the new Minister.

articles.title: Burnt mansions: Why the next election is a fork in the road
articles.summary: Joëlle Gergis is a climate scientist and contributor to The Saturday Paper. She is concerned about the impact of climate change on the poor and the upcoming election in Australia. She believes the next election is a fork in the road for the future of the climate.

articles.title: Trump to visit western NC in first visit as president
articles.author: Erika Williams
articles.summary: Donald Trump is expected to visit western North Carolina on Friday. The area was devastated by Hurricane Helene in late September, killing more than 100 people and leaving thousands without shelter. Buncombe County officials released a statement on Thursday warning residents to be ready for increased traffic from 11-2 p.m.

articles.title: Better digital literacy could help reduce climate and disaster conspiracy theories
articles.author: S. Harris Ali
articles.summary: In recent years, the proliferation of conspiracy theories amid escalating climate disasters and their aftermath has become an alarming trend. People tend to accept information that aligns with their pre-existing beliefs, cultural norms and identities. They can erode public trust in scientists and scientific evidence, impede the acceptance of climate science and the adoption of climate mitigation strategies. Online platforms like X and Meta have weakened their fact-checking mechanisms. Governments need to adopt a more proactive stance in combating climate change denialism.

articles.title: Lamont details his agenda for making Conn. more resilient to extreme weather
articles.author: Claudia S. Hilario
articles.summary: Governor Ned Lamont announced a detailed legislative plan to address Connecticut's growing vulnerability to extreme weather and climate change. 'Each year is bringing an increased number of extreme weather events and abnormal climate patterns that are direct threats to our homes and our lives,' Lamont said.

articles.title: We are in a new era
articles.author: Daily Gate City
articles.summary: 2024 will be the hottest year on record, according to scientists. The world has entered a new era of chaotic times, as Los Angeles burned for days on end, and scientists are warning that the world is in a dangerous new era.

articles.title: Area schools announce closures, remote learning on Friday
articles.author: Shea Carver
articles.summary: Cape Fear Academy is closed on Friday, Jan. 24. New Hanover County Schools cancel classes. Brunswick County Schools will continue asynchronous remote learning on Friday. Pender County Schools are closed except for Pender Early College. Extra-curricular activities are canceled through Saturday.

articles.title: Letter: My opinion on ‘Global Warming'
articles.author: Local Submission
articles.summary: As of 2022, there were 5,589 ships in the global fleet. They use mainly bunker fuel which is high in sulphur and generates harmful emissions. It contains 2,000 times as much sulphur as diesel used in U.S., European automobiles. 16 container ships produce as much pollution as 35 million gas-fired vehicles.

articles.title: What's biting: coastal challenges and long weekend fishing outlook
articles.author: Columnist Kate Shelton
articles.summary: The past week has seen a period of significant swell on the coastline presenting challenging conditions for anglers, especially on the coastlines.    for the past week, the coastline has seen significant swell. For more information, visit the Angler's Guide's website.

articles.title: Trump executive orders cause concern for North Carolina environmental community
articles.author: Christine Zhu
articles.summary: President Donald Trump signed a flurry of executive orders on the environment within hours of his return to the White House this week. Environmentalists are worried about the impact of the orders on climate change and global warming. Trump is scheduled to visit the hurricane-damaged western portion of North Carolina on Friday.

articles.title: Extreme climate caused West Greenland lakes to brown
articles.author: Stacy Blanchet
articles.summary: After extreme weather events in fall 2022, an estimated 7,500 lakes in West Greenland turned brown, began emitting carbon and decreased in water quality. Extreme weather events caused by several atmospheric rivers. The increase in dissolved organic carbon and nutrients from the permafrost can promote bacteria growth and produce an undesirable taste and odor in the water. Increased exposure to metals released from permafrosts can cause health problems.

articles.title: Amid climate extremes, CT lawmakers set sights on resiliency efforts
articles.author: Connecticut Public Radio
articles.summary: Connecticut's governor and Senate leadership announced two bills this week focused on preparing cities and towns for future impacts of climate change. President Donald Trump has started the process to take the U.S. out of the Paris Climate agreement. The summer flooding alone cost hundreds of millions in damage and Connecticut required federal help in the recovery. Governor Ned Lamont will deliver his budget address on Feb. 5 and file the bill.

articles.title: Storm-ravaged North Carolina faces new hurdle in fighting floods
articles.author: Miranda Willson
articles.summary: President Donald Trump is visiting western North Carolina on Friday. The state legislature passed a law restricting local zoning authorities in the wake of Hurricane Helene. Some local officials fear it will make it more difficult for hard-hit cities like Asheville to clamp down on development in flood-prone areas. It could also cause more people to lose out on flood insurance.

articles.title: Winter Weather Worse? 64% Blame Climate Change
articles.summary: 44% of American Adults say this winter has been worse where they live than it has been in past years. 46% say this year's winter has not been worse, and 10% are not sure. The survey of 1,302 American Adults was conducted on January 16 and 19-20, 2025. The margin of sampling error is 2 percentage points with a 95% level of confidence.

articles.title: Without FEMA, ‘more people would have died' in Helene: Resident
articles.author: Steph Whiteside
articles.summary: President Donald Trump wants to visit western North Carolina to see the damage from Hurricane Helene. James Green, who lives in Asheville, North Carolina, was without water for weeks after the storm. He believes FEMA and the Red Cross did a great job in the aftermath of the hurricane.

articles.title: Canada to experience another year of record-breaking heat
articles.summary: Canadians are in for another year of record-breaking heat, according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's latest report. The Canadian Centre for Climate Change Modelling Analysis forecasts a global mean surface temperature of 1.45°C above pre-industrial levels in 2025. Last year was the hottest year globally on record and the first year to exceed the 1.5°C threshold established by the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Dr. Dion George Urges the U.S. to Uphold Global Climate Commitments
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Dr. Dion George, South Africa's Minister of Forestry, Fisheries, and the Environment has strongly condemned the United States' decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. The Paris Agreement was adopted in 2015 to limit global temperature increases to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and cap the rise at 1.5°C. South Africa has called for enhanced international cooperation to curb emissions, innovate solutions, and mitigate the effects of global warming.

articles.title: How Will La Niña Impact North American Industries?
articles.author: Jim Foerster
articles.summary: After a warm start to winter, La Niña is changing the weather patterns in North America. Businesses need to prepare for more typical weather patterns. The Pacific Northwest will see cooler, wetter conditions with heavy mountain snowfall, the southern U.S. will see warmer, drier weather, while the Midwest and Northeast will see an increased risk of cold snaps and snowstorms.

articles.title: A Longstanding Struggle Against Displacement
articles.author: IEye News
articles.summary: This week's Island Innovation newsletter brings you the latest insights and developments from island communities around the world. Cabo Verde Country Climate and Development Report reveals a dual reality on the one hand, and on the other, opportunities for innovation and sustainability. Extra early bird prices for the Global Sustainable Islands Summit 2025 are ending on January 31st. Saint Kitts & Nevis has been recognised for its efforts in sustainable development.

articles.title: Israel Migrant Birds
articles.author: ASC
articles.summary: Migrating cranes flock at sunrise in Hula Lake conservation area, north of the Sea of Galilee, northern Israel, on Thursday, Jan. 23, 2025. (AP Photo/Ariel Schalit)    i   in

articles.title: APTOPIX Israel Migrant Birds
articles.author: ASC
articles.summary: Migrating cranes flock at sunrise in Hula Lake conservation area, north of the Sea of Galilee, in northern Israel, on Thursday, Jan. 23, 2025. (AP Photo/Ariel Schalit)   .   i

articles.title: Luxembourg MPs debate adapting employee protections
articles.author: Maxime Gillen  adapted
articles.summary: Luxembourg's Chamber of Deputies held a debate on Thursday morning to discuss the impact of climate change on working conditions. MPs agreed that existing frameworks for employee protection must be updated to address the growing health risks posed by rising temperatures and extreme weather events. The minister of Labour emphasised the importance of collaboration with the Inspectorate of Labour and Mines and other relevant bodies to implement necessary changes.

articles.title: Anguish, despair and grief due to climate crisis are valid psychological responses
articles.author: Lauren McGregor
articles.summary: There is a growing concern about the impact of climate change on people's lives. Psychologists say people are not alone and there is no correct way to feel about it. People should focus on context when making sense of distress and connect with other people who share the same concerns.

articles.title: Fears that the world's biggest iceberg could hit island in the South Atlantic
articles.author: system
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, A23a, is still on the move and there are fears that it could be headed north from Antarctica towards the island of South Georgia. The iceberg was previously 'trapped' spinning around an undersea mountain. It is currently in a meander of the current and not moving directly towards the Island.

articles.title: NDMA participates in Regional Consultative Committee forum in Thailand
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Pakistan's delegation participated in the 18th meeting of the Regional Consultative Committee (RCC) in Bangkok, Thailand on Thursday. RCC is a regional forum to promote consultation and cooperation in reducing disaster and climate change risk in Asia and the Pacific region. The theme of this year's RCC meeting is 'Sustainable Anticipatory Actions for Resilient Development Goals'.

articles.title: Impact Of Climate Change On Humans' Overall Health Image Credit: Unsplash
articles.author: NDTV Doctor
articles.summary: Climate change is not just an environmental concern, it directly impacts human health. It is causing various physical and mental health challenges worldwide. It's not just a matter of environmental concerns, it's also a health concern. It directly impacts people's physical, mental and social lives.

articles.title: The Philippines' urgent call for climate action and resilience
articles.author: Erika Mioten
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures, intensifying natural disasters, and widespread environmental degradation have all been the topic of headlines in the past year. Last year, the Philippines was hit by six consecutive storm systems that left around 200,000 Filipinos displaced across six regions. The United Nations' sustainable development goals call for action to combat climate change.

articles.title: Snowiest day? Worcester winter weather records
articles.author: Telegram
articles.summary: Worcester has had the snowiest calendar year with 133.1 inches in 1996. The snowiest day was January 27, 2015. February was the coldest month with 53.4 inches of snow. The coldest temperature was 14.2 degrees in February 2015.

articles.title: Arkansas Wildlife Weekly Waterfowl Report: Midwinter survey shows jump; total duck count below 1M in Arkansas Delta
articles.author: Stuttgart Daily Leader
articles.summary: Arkansas Game and Fish Commission's annual Midwinter Aerial Survey showed a jump in ducks and mallards from estimates of those categories a year ago in the state. The waterfowl biologists estimated 452,017 mallards and 924,545 total ducks in the Delta. Duck counts in the Arkansas River Valley totaled 84,119 ducks, including 39,058 mallards. Arctic goose population estimates totaled 615,756 lesser snow and 189,166 greater white-fronted geese (specklebellies).

articles.title: Climate and environment updates: Funders to cover US after Paris Agreement withdrawal
articles.summary: Bloomberg Philanthropies, along with a coalition of climate charities, announced Thursday that they will step up and ensure that the U.S. meets its obligations under the Paris Agreement, including financial and reporting requirements. President Donald Trump announced his intention to withdraw the United States from Paris Agreement on Monday. This is the second time Trump has withdrawn the country from the international climate treaty.

articles.title: Little birds with tiny backpacks solving big problems
articles.author: Matt Simmons
articles.summary: Birds Canada, a national conservation group, launched the Motus project about a decade ago, partnering with individuals and organizations around the world. Every year, tens of millions of birds take to the skies along migratory routes like the Pacific Flyway, an aerial artery that stretches from Alaska to Patagonia. The Motus network allows researchers to share information about individual birds as they cross borders using radio tags.

articles.title: ‘North Dakota Outdoors' webcast highlights annual midwinter waterfowl survey
articles.author: North Dakota
articles.summary: The North Dakota Game and Fish Department's annual midwinter waterfowl survey in early January indicated about 88,000 Canada geese and 3,225 mallards in the state. Mike Anderson visits with John Palarski, the migratory game bird biologist on this week's "North Dakota Outdoors".

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on imminent collision course with British island
articles.author: James King
articles.summary: The largest iceberg in the world is heading towards South Georgia, a British territory 173 miles (280 km) north of Antarctica. It poses a potential threat to local wildlife, including penguins and seals. A network of scientists, sailors, and fishermen worldwide is monitoring the iceberg through satellite imagery.

articles.title: Canada Invests in Climate Change Adaptation to Keep Communities Safe in Southern Ontario and Across Canada Français
articles.author: Natural Resources Canada
articles.summary: Julie Dabrusin, Parliamentary Secretary to the Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson and Bardish Chagger, Member of Parliament for Toronto–Danforth, announced $4.5 million in funding for nine projects in southern Ontario. The projects aim to enhance knowledge and skills among professionals, businesses and communities to adapt to a changing climate.

articles.title: The 5 states Americans moved to in 2024 — and the 5 states they left
articles.author: Madeline Fitzgerald
articles.summary: The number of Americans moving due to environmental conditions increased by 121% in 2024. California, Texas and Florida led the nation in terms of the overall number of people moving in, but none of the three states cracked the top three spots in the overall migration chart.

articles.title: South Africa reacts to United States of America's withdrawal from Paris Agreement (Department of Forestry and Fisheries and the Environment - Republic of South Africa)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The Minister of Forestry, Fisheries and the Environment, Dr Dion George, has expressed profound regret over the decision of the United States of America to withdraw from the Paris Agreement again. The adoption of the Paris agreement was a result of the UN General Assembly's decision.

articles.title: After brutally cold weather, temperatures to slowly warm in New Hampshire
articles.author: Kevin Skarupa
articles.summary: Kevin Skarupa has a look at a warming trend back to seasonable levels in the video he has shared with the world. He finds it a good sign for the future of the climate.   Â. Â   y

articles.title: Area school closures, delays for Thursday, Jan. 23
articles.author: Cumberland Times-News
articles.summary: Mineral County Schools, Allegany County Public Schools and Alhambra Public Schools are on a two-hour delay for Thursday, Jan. 23, 2025, due to inclement weather. Hardy County Schools are closed, non-traditional learning. Hampshire County Schools and Morgan County Schools have a delay. Grant County Schools has a delay of two hours.

articles.title: ‘A hugely significant sighting': red goshawk photographed for first time in central Australia
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: The red goshawk, Australia's rarest bird of prey, was photographed in central Australia for the first time in 30 years. Red goshawks are threatened by habitat loss, mining, agriculture, forestry and urban development, as well as changing patterns of bushfire.

articles.title: Letter: Los Angeles fires predictable
articles.author: Vancouver
articles.summary: There was a two-year drought and lax water conservation in the Los Angeles Basin. The Santa Ana winds come up off the Mojave Desert and pick up speed as they rush down the mountains and into the canyons. Many people will move out and flee to the north to find jobs.

articles.title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR: LA fires and climate change
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are highly unusual in southern California in January, which is supposed to be the rainy season. In Europe, extreme heat contributed to at least 47,000 deaths in 2023 and heat-related deaths have doubled in the U.S.

articles.title: UNESCO, WMO launch International Year of Glaciers' Preservation 2025
articles.author: Arailym Temirgaliyeva
articles.summary: The first World Day for Glaciers will be celebrated at UNESCO's Headquarters in Paris on March 20-21. 2025 was proclaimed by the UN General Assembly as the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation to raise awareness about the role of glaciers, snow and ice in the climate system and water cycle.

articles.title: Elk Mills and Poga dominate latest Carter County recovery update
articles.author: Carter County
articles.summary: Carter County Mayor Patty Woodby gave her weekly update of the county's recovery from Hurricane Helene. Poga and Elk Mills are recovering from the hurricane. Temporary bridges over the Elk River and the weekly medical clinic are being set up in Poga, Elk Mills.

articles.title: Sahel: Climate Change and Resource Competition
articles.author: Sofia Eve Mathew
articles.summary: The semiarid region of the Sahel in Africa south of the Sahara Desert is threatened by climate change, erratic rainfall and frequent floods. The region has one of the world's highest concentrations of solar energy. The African Development Bank's Desert to Power initiative is using solar energy to power 250 million people in the region by 2030. The initiative is a significant program to rehabilitate degraded areas and protect deserts.

articles.title: Mekong Delta provinces grow more mangroves to prevent coastal erosion
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Authorities in the Mekong Delta are implementing various programmes to grow mangrove forests to protect coastal areas and improve the incomes of local people. Ca Mau has lost 5,200 ha of mangroves in the past 10 years and 190km of its 254km coastline is suffering from erosion. Ben Tre province has planted 205ha of new forests and regenerated 82ha of natural forests since 2020. Soc Trang launched a project aimed at increasing the coastal resilience of the delta.

articles.title: Turkey needs effective agricultural planning to increase production
articles.summary: Experts in Türkiye are calling for improved planning, enhanced education and sustainable practices to ensure the country's food security and foster rural development. Murat Kapikiran, head of the Istanbul Chamber of Agricultural Engineers, proposed establishing democratic cooperatives to help farmers self-regulate, increase profitability, and tackle financial and supply chain challenges. Fevzi Cicek, president of the Malatya Agricultural Vocational School, stressed the need to produce more than it consumes to avoid dependency and poverty.

articles.title: Iceberg visible from space puts South Georgia Island, wildlife in danger
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, A23a, is drifting from Antarctica toward South Georgia, a remote British island renowned for its diverse wildlife. It is just 173 miles (280km) away and risks grounding and breaking apart, potentially.   "I would be extraordinarily happy if it just completely missed us"

articles.title: Hurricane Helene Victims Fighting Weather; Seeking Answers
articles.author: Sandy Fitzgerald
articles.summary: It's cold this winter in Florida, North Carolina and Georgia. It's been four months since Hurricane Helene and two weeks since Hurricane Milton hit the area. Some people still don't have their power back on and their homes are damaged from the last two storms.

articles.title: Climate Action Is the 2025 Health Resolution We All Need
articles.author: James Taylor
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record. Wildfires have claimed lives and destroyed homes in California. Wildfire smoke increases breathing complications in children and the number of heat related deaths has been on the rise across the country. Health sector in the United States is responsible for about 8.5 percent of the carbon footprint.

articles.title: Above-Average Temperatures Could Dominate Much Of US As Winter Hands Off To Spring
articles.author: Caitlin Kaiser
articles.summary: The Weather Company and Atmospheric G2 have released an outlook for the last month of winter and early spring in the U.S. from February to April. It's expected that above-average temperatures are expected from the Southwest across much of the Plains and East. In contrast, the Northwest and parts of the Northern Plains are expected to see cooler than average temperatures as we move into spring.

articles.title: Antigua and Barbuda Face Mixed Drought Conditions For 2025
articles.summary: Antigua and Barbuda, including the Caribbean is experiencing mixed drought conditions as the 2025 dry season begins. Conditions ranged from dry in Trinidad and Aruba to extremely dry in parts of northern Guyana and northwestern Suriname. Forecasts for the first quarter of 2025 indicate normal to above-normal rainfall for the eastern Caribbean, but the northwest could see below-normal precipitation.

articles.title: Off the news: Green on hunt for climate change funds
articles.author: Star Advertiser
articles.summary: An estimated $500 million annually is needed to shore up Hawaii's climate-change defenses and respond to the increased risks of fire, flood, and storm-related disaster.   .   "$500 million a year" is estimated to be needed to protect Hawaii from climate change.

articles.title: The Arctic: climate change's great economic opportunity
articles.author: The Economist
articles.summary: The Arctic is warming four times faster than the rest of the world. Since the 1980s the volume of ice has fallen by 70% or more. The Arctic's first ice-free day may occur before 2030, according to some scientists.

articles.title: Coral bleaching on Australia's Great Barrier Reef reaches 'catastrophic' levels due to..., here's what study
articles.author: Meemansa Shekhawat
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef in Australia's Coral Sea is experiencing its worst summer ever. Over 50 per cent of the corals were killed last year during the most "severe and widespread bleaching". The burning of planet-heating fossil fuels have led to a rise in global temperatures. El Niño weather pattern, which heats ocean temperatures in this part of the world, can also be blamed for the coral damage.

articles.title: Coral bleaching on Australia's Great Barrier Reef reaches 'catastrophic' levels due to..., here's what study says
articles.author: Meemansa Shekhawat
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef in Coral Sea, Australia is experiencing its worst summer in 2024. Over 50 per cent of the corals were killed last year during the most "severe and widespread bleaching". The burning of planet-heating fossil fuels has led to a rise in global temperatures. El Niño weather pattern can also be blamed for the coral damage.

articles.title: Rwanda: Weather Agency On Why Country Will Experience Low Rainfall Next Quarter
articles.author: Michel Nkurunziza
articles.summary: Rwanda will receive between 250 millimeters and 550 millimeters of rainfall from March to May 2025. La Niña in the Pacific Ocean and the neutral conditions in the Indian Ocean Dipole are the main factors that will affect rainfall. The weather agency advised public institutions, NGOs, private sector and the general public to use the seasonal forecast in their planning and decision-making to increase productivity and mitigate risks associated with prevailing weather conditions.

articles.title: US exit from Paris Agreement sparks climate concerns
articles.summary: Tanzania has experienced a significant temperature rise in 2024, averaging 0.7 degrees Celsius. This trend threatens agriculture and natural resources, which are crucial to the country's economy. The Journalists' Environmental Association of Tanzania (JET) highlighted the potential financial impact of the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Canada Invests in Climate Change Adaptation to Keep Communities Safe in Southern Ontario and Across Canada
articles.summary: Julie Dabrusin, Parliamentary Secretary to the Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson and Bardish Chagger, Member of Parliament for Waterloo, announced over $4.5 million in funding for nine projects in southern Ontario. The projects aim to enhance knowledge and skills among professionals, businesses and communities to adapt to a changing climate.

articles.title: Adapting to change: How local farmers use tradition to combat climate impacts sustainably
articles.author: Naledi Sikhakhane
articles.summary: Experts shared survival tactics at a virtual seminar titled Indigenous Approaches to Adaptation hosted by Rural Change for Climate Adaptation Organisation, Social Change Assistance Trust, Heinrich Boll Stiftung and other partners. Director of Sustaining the Wild Coast and winner of the 2024 Goldman Prize for the environment, Sinegugu Zukulu, was one of three speakers. He said farmers have created climate adaptation strategies born out of necessity.

articles.title: Emergency warnings for WA bushfire
articles.summary: Emergency warnings for WA bushfire are currently unavailable. We're working to restore it. Please try to use the feature again later, as it's unavailable at the moment.   .   - we're sorry, this feature is currently unavailable and will be restored later.

articles.title: New research uncovers major downside in waiting to address impending 'tipping point': 'Asymmetry is important for us to consider'
articles.author: Leo Collis
articles.summary: Scientists have long been concerned about the Earth reaching a climate tipping point, when changes to the planet's natural systems trigger various environmental catastrophes. The study found that the effort and cost to reverse these changes will become significantly higher once these thresholds have been passed. However, there is a brief window of opportunity where intervention costs increase only slightly.

articles.title: Letter: Time to prepare for our next fire season
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: After 50 years of global warming denial, there is no more time for denial. Now is the time to prepare for the next fire season. We need to act now in implementing our City of Fire Prevention Act.   Already subscribed to this news service?

articles.title: The 5 states Americans moved to in 2024 — and the 5 states they left
articles.author: Madeline Fitzgerald
articles.summary: The number of Americans moving due to environmental conditions increased by 121% in 2024. California, Texas, and Florida led the nation in terms of the overall number of people moving in, but none of the three cracked the top ten states with the largest net migration gains in the 2024-25 HireAHelper Migration Report. Relatively few people changed their addresses in the last year.

articles.title: IMF: Climate resilience could boost Bahamas' economy by 9%
articles.author: Natario Mckenzie
articles.summary: Investing in climate resilience could boost economic output by 9 percent over the next three-quarters of a century, according to the International Monetary Fund. Modernizing electricity grids and increasing the share of solar energy and liquefied natural gas in electricity production could yield major macroeconomic benefits for The Bahamas.

articles.title: Letter: Leaving Paris Climate Agreement is a mistake
articles.author: Wendy Fry
articles.summary: The president's decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement is deplorable, writes John Sutter. Sutter: "Shock and awe" is not the right response to the president's decisions. "Deplorable decisions" are one of them, he adds.

articles.title: High Levels Of Toxic Algae In Wairarapa And Hutt Valley Rivers
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Greater Wellington's senior advisor Penny Fairbrother says the warm weather means toxic algae has 'exploded' across the region.    "Toxic algae has exploded" in the Greater Wellington region, according to Fairbrother. "It's a very serious problem."

articles.title: Earth breaks yearly heat record and lurches past dangerous warming threshold
articles.author: In Partnership With
articles.summary: Earth recorded its hottest year ever in 2024. It's the first time in recorded history that the planet was above a hoped-for limit to warming for an entire year. Last year's global average temperature easily passed 2023's record heat and kept going. It surpassed the long-term warming limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) that was called for by the 2015 Paris climate pact. There were 27 billion-dollar disasters in the U.S. in 2024, including Hurricane Helene and Hurricane Michael.

articles.title: The case for the carbon fee and dividend
articles.author: Jenna Pontecorvo
articles.summary: Global warming has been a highlighted topic in the news for a long time now. Climate change is affecting almost every state in the USA, including New Jersey. The fires in Los Angeles, the floods in Fort Lauderdale, Florida and the storms in New Jersey have been caused by climate change.

articles.title: Two to Eight tropical cyclones likely from January to June, says PAGASA
articles.author: Agar Wal Ekwensi
articles.summary: After a series of tropical cyclones in October and November, PAGASA forecasts the development of two to eight tropicalcyclones in the first half of 2025. Ana Liza S. Solis, Assistant Weather Services Chief and Chief of the Climate Monitoring and Prediction Section of PAGasA shares her insights.

articles.title: 'Volcanoes Will Erupt': Scientists Sound The Alarm, Explain How Life On Earth Will End
articles.author: Parishmita Saikia
articles.summary: Bristol University scientists predict that Earth will be destroyed in 250 million years due to extreme heat and CO2 levels. All living things on Earth, including humans, will disappear. The Earth's temperature will reach 70 degrees Celsius, and volcanoes will erupt, releasing huge levels of carbon dioxide.

articles.title: Sound off: We are in a new era
articles.author: Ron Sadler
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster, storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture, and soaring temperatures worldwide are leading to heat waves and drought. In Europe, extreme heat contributed to at least 47,000 deaths in 2023. In the United States, heat-related deaths have doubled in recent decades.

articles.title: Karnataka shivers in cold wave: Dharwad hits lowest 10.6°C, alerts IMD
articles.author: Vinaykumar Patil
articles.summary: Karnataka is experiencing a week of intense cold, with temperatures dropping each day. The cold wave has brought foggy mornings across several parts of the state, with some regions recording unusually low temperatures. The IMD urges residents to take precautions against the cold and to stay warm and cautious while travelling in foggy conditions.

articles.title: Rwanda says 2024 hottest year on record
articles.author: Michel Nkurunziza
articles.summary: Rwanda has recorded 2024 as the hottest year on record, with temperatures 1.1 degrees Celsius higher than those before the industrial revolution. The last rainy season saw lower amounts of rainfall than the same season in 2023. The amount of rainfall in the last four months of 2024 was below forecast levels, which affected farmers in various parts of the country. The past decade comprises the 10 warmest years on record.

articles.title: Australian Open in pictures: A collection of AP photos showing the light and shade of the tournament
articles.author: Manish Swarup
articles.summary: The Australian Open tennis tournament is taking place in Melbourne. "A collection of some of the top photos by Associated Press photographers show the intense light and shade of the tournament.

articles.title: Meet Kenya's climate refugees

Somalia's agro-pastoralist economy is being hit the hardest by the multiplying droughts and floods. Somalia was ranked the world's most vulnerable country out of 185 countries studied by the University of Notre Dame. The government and the Department of Refugee Services have not released information regarding how refugees can integrate into local communities.

articles.title: Rain, floods & storms: why our weather conditions are getting wetter
articles.author: RTÉ Brainstorm
articles.summary: Storm Éowyn is due to hit Ireland in the next 24 hours. There are warnings that it will be one of the worst storms Ireland has ever seen. 2023 was the wettest year on record in Ireland and rainfall in the early months of 2024 was above average.

articles.summary: The water bordered by the Southern United States, Mexico and Cuba will be called the Gulf of Mexico or Gulf of America. Juneau's leaders are planning tax hikes and shunning pleas from needy agencies for funds as they confront flood-protection projects that could cost hundreds of millions of dollars. There have been 403 weather and climate disasters since 1980, with damages/costs exceeding $1 billion in inflation-adjusted dollars. Alaska is experiencing economic struggles both in the governmental and private sectors.

articles.title: The RSPB Big Garden Birdwatch 2025 project in Norfolk
articles.author: Jo Taylor
articles.summary: Big Garden Birdwatch has been taking place for four decades. Blue tit and great tit have seen their numbers rise by 24% and 61%. Starling numbers have dropped by 80% since 1979. Long-tailed tits were found in more than 33% of Norfolk gardens. Redwings saw a 105% increase in Norfolk gardens last year compared to 2023. The next event takes place on January 24, 25 and 26.

articles.title: How to take part in the RSPB Big Garden Birdwatch 2025 in Norfolk
articles.author: Jo Taylor
articles.summary: Big Garden Birdwatch has been taking place for four decades. Blue tit and great tit have seen their numbers rise by 24% and 61%. Starling numbers have dropped by 80% since 1979. Long-tailed tits were found in more than 33% of Norfolk gardens. Redwings and fieldfares visited gardens more often. The next event takes place on January 24, 25 and 26 with registration opening on December 11.

articles.title: Trump pulls out of Paris Climate Agreement
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: Donald Trump has signed an Executive Order to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement. It aims to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The Met Office warns the planet is 'off track' to keep temperatures down. Kumi Naidoo is a climate justice activist.

articles.title: Climate change brews trouble in Brazil
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: Coffee lovers are likely to see an increase of between 30 to 40 percent in global coffee prices this year. Extreme weather in Brazil and Vietnam is impacting supply of coffee beans. Nestle warns coffee lovers they will pay even more for their daily brews.

articles.title: ‘Political football' being played over LA wildfires
articles.summary: President Donald Trump is going to survey the recovery efforts in North Carolina and California. North Carolina was devastated by Hurricane Helene in late September 2024, while Los Angeles continues to be ravaged by horrific wildfires. Republicans in Congress are trying to figure out how to deal with the situation.

articles.title: East, Southern Africa Focus on Adaptation Plans

articles.summary: The escalating impacts of climate-induced disasters are devastating vulnerable communities in East and Southern Africa. To protect people, livelihoods and economies, countries must prioritize the development and implementation of National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), which serve as crucial roadmaps to build climate resilience. Only seven countries in the region have finalized and submitted their NAPs.

articles.title: Coral bleaching on Australia's Great Barrier Reef reaches ‘catastrophic' levels, study finds
articles.author: Helen Regan
articles.summary: Record ocean heat has taken a devastating toll on one of the world's greatest natural wonders, with coral bleaching on Australia's Great Barrier Reef reaching 'catastrophic' levels. More than 50% of affected corals monitored near an island in the reef's south were killed last year. The culprit is the burning of planet-heating fossil fuels.

articles.title: Kenya: Isiolo Loses 190,000 Acres of Grassland Amid an Unrelenting Wildfire
articles.summary: Isiolo County is battling a devastating wildfire that has ravaged over 190,000 acres of grassland. The fire has been raging for the fifth day on Wednesday. It poses a severe threat to wildlife, livestock, and livelihoods in the arid region. The County Commissioner has called on humanitarian agencies to provide support.

articles.title: How extreme weather came to rule the climate change roost
articles.author: Bill Ponton
articles.summary: The term 'extreme weather' came into the popular lexicon after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans in 2005. Mainstream media used the term as part of an effort to raise fear about climate change due to anthropogenic global warming. The empirical data does not support the extreme weather narrative.

articles.title: How you can help Britain's birds survive this winter
articles.author: David Overend
articles.summary: Winter can be tough for birdlife but there are things we can do to help them. The RSPB's Big Garden Bird Watch asks for the nation's help in counting garden birds between 24 and 26 January. David Overend is feeding Robin and knows many of his fellow feeders.

articles.title: Demise of Australia's large kangaroos likely not caused climate change, study suggests
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: Dental analysis suggests that the extinction of Australia's prehistoric kangaroos was not caused by climate change. The arrival of humans played a more significant role than previously thought more than 40,000 years ago. The four most common species found throughout Australia and nearby New Guinea are the red, eastern grey, western grey and antilopine kangaroo.

articles.title: 11 years of broken promises leave Yolanda survivors in housing despair
articles.author: Herbie G
articles.summary: Eleven years after Super Typhoon Yolanda devastated the country, survivors are still waiting for promised housing. The National Housing Authority owes survivors nearly 31,000 homes. Only 171,230 of the 202,000 housing units have been built. P6.456 billion of the P32.057 billion for the YPHP was redirected to unrelated projects.

articles.title: Why Is It So Cold in the South If the Planet Is Warming? Here's What We Know.

articles.author: Aubrey Whelan
articles.summary: A snow goose in Philadelphia's Carroll Park neighborhood is the city's first suspected case of a highly contagious avian flu. The goose was found on Jan. 11 on the 1200 block of North 59th Street. Preliminary testing from state agriculture officials indicated the bird had avian influenza.

articles.title: Earth's Magnetic North Pole Is Officially Moving – Scientists Just Updated Its Location
articles.author: David Nield
articles.summary: The position of the magnetic North Pole is being changed. It's moving away from Canada and towards Siberia. The new World Magnetic Model (WMM) is more accurate than the old one. Major airlines will upgrade their navigation software to load in the new model. Military navigation systems will also need to be updated.

articles.title: Earth's Magnetic North Pole Is Officially Moving – Scientists Just Updated Its Location
articles.author: David Nield
articles.summary: The World Magnetic Model 2025 was released on December 31st to all Flight Service platforms. It's time to update navigation systems on ships, airplanes and militaries as the position of the magnetic North Pole is being changed. Magnetic north has been moving slowly around Canada since the 1500s but in the past 20 years it accelerated towards Siberia.

articles.title: NZ's climate policies are no longer enough to keep warming at 1.5°C—here's what needs to happen
articles.author: Robert McLachlan
articles.summary: Last year was the warmest year on record globally and the first to exceed 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. New Zealand's 2050 climate target has two components: Methane emissions from livestock must be cut by 24% to 47% below 2017 levels and emissions of all other greenhouse gases must reach net zero. The commission has made three main recommendations to raise ambition.

articles.title: Securing Pakistan's agricultural future
articles.author: Dr M Bilal Tahir
articles.summary: Pakistan's economy is heavily reliant on Rabi and Kharif crops. The country's major crops, including wheat, rice, maize and sugarcane, are at risk due to rising temperatures and unpredictable weather patterns. The agriculture sector is a cornerstone of Pakistan's economy, contributing about 24% to the GDP and providing employment to 37.4% of the labour force. The Ministry of National Food Security and Research reports a promising 6.25% growth in the agricultural sector during the fiscal year 2023-24, signalling its importance for the country's economy.

articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record for the planet, and the first to go 1.5 C above pre-industrial temperatures. Environment Canada has released its first publicly available annual global mean temperature forecast for 2025. It is expected to be hotter than every January to December period on record prior to the past two years. The forecast is compiled with version 3 of the Canadian Seasonal to Inter-annual Prediction System (CanSIPS).

articles.title: Food security in the face of climate change
articles.author: Dzul
articles.summary: Malaysia's food prices have risen by 2.6% year-on-year as of November 2024, the highest increase since December 2023. articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit Florida's Big Bend region last fall, killing dozens of people. Then-President Biden threatened to withhold federal aid for purely political reasons. He blamed the destruction on the climate denial of Florida's Republican governor, Rick Scott. Scott denies this.

articles.title: War's carbon bootprint: Why climate action demands peace
articles.author: Gulf News
articles.summary: "The basic science is well established that global warming is due to greenhouse gases. What is uncertain is projections about specifics in the next few decades, by how much will the climate change happen. "The future of the planet is uncertain" says Mexican scientist.

articles.title: Shipping set to blow its carbon budget as it fails to future-proof its fleet
articles.author: Tradewinds
articles.summary: The shipping industry is overshooting a greenhouse gas emission cap, according to researchers from University College London's Bartlett Energy Institute. The industry needs to reduce emissions to contribute to minimising the impact of global warming, they say. The research was published in the journal, "The Global Warming Policy.

articles.title: Why Is It So Cold in the South If the Planet Is Warming? Here's What ...
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: A mass of air called the polar vortex has escaped the Arctic and plunged southward. Some scientists see the fingerprints of climate change on the phenomenon. The polar vortex may be caused by climate change, according to some scientists. The cause of this phenomenon is unknown.

articles.title: An underestimated source of methane found in shallow coastal waters
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Shallow coastal waters are hotspots for methane emissions, releasing significant amounts of this potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, which contributes to global warming.   .      in the atmosphere and in shallow coastal waters. In the sea, methane emissions are high.

articles.title: My Climate Protest Arrest Shows the Problem with ‘Social Tipping Point' Theory
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: People hoping that progress on climate action will accelerate must prepare for a long, hard struggle, as it will not be like sudden changes in our physical world, as some have suggested.    “People hoping for a sudden change in climate change will not get it.”

articles.title: Winners and losers
articles.author: Rapid City Journal
articles.summary: The compounding effects of global warming will overwhelm our ability for mitigation if not addressed earnestly in the immediate future. Trump's intent is to decimate current efforts, and to ignore current scientific evidence.    i   in the end, the only solution is to address the problem now.

articles.title: Climate Change Could Cut the Economy in Half. We're Not Ready for It.
articles.author: The New Republic
articles.summary: Climate change might torch 50 percent of the world's GDP by mid-century, according to my son's late middle age, and I'll say that.    I'll say it later this century towards his teenage son's mid-middle age.

articles.title: Stay off the ice! Toms River, Barnegat Bay may freeze, but you'd probably fall through
articles.author: app
articles.summary: Iceboating in New Jersey is under threat due to changing climate conditions, says Jim Gervolino, winter fleet captain of the Long Branch Ice Boat & Yacht Club. He talks to Doug Hood of the Asbury Park Press about it.

articles.title: Turning the financial tide for small island states
articles.author: Project Syndicate/Nassau/Malé
articles.summary: Small island developing states (SIDS) are on the front lines of climate change. SIDS are home to 40 percent of the world's coral reefs, which shelter one-quarter of all marine life and directly support the livelihoods of 500 million people. Their ecosystems play a crucial role in global climate mitigation and adaptation, but SIDS face negative feedback loops from interconnected economic and environmental challenges. The key to breaking these feedback loops is more financing.

articles.title: Bahamas in $1bn boost via climate resilient investment
articles.author: NEIL HARTNELL
articles.summary: The Bahamas will boost its long-term economic output by over $1bn if it starts investing in climate-resilient infrastructure and protecting natural assets such as beaches and mangroves, the IMF is urging. The Washington D.C. based Fund argues that heavy spending on mitigation and adaptation measures now could reverse what is forecast to be an up to 11% decline in Bahamian GDP by 2100 if no action is taken.

articles.title: Make use of rainfall updates, agro-sector stakeholders told
articles.author: Joseph Prosper
articles.summary: The Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA) has urged stakeholders across various economic sectors to plan their activities in line with updated seasonal forecasts to avoid disasters. The agriculture sector risks excessive moisture and potential flooding. The livestock and fisheries sector faces considerable risk of livestock diseases like Rift Valley fever and foot and mouth disease. In transport, both excessive and insufficient rainfall could damage roads and railways, leading to accidents.

articles.title: First Take: About the idea of renaming the Gulf of Mexico
articles.author:
CESAR NEYOY
BAJO EL SOL
articles.summary: The presidential proposal to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America has caused more laughter and ridicule than fear or concern in the neighboring country. Mexicans continue calling institutions and places by their old names even years after they've been officially changed. Even if the Gulf is unilaterally renamed, they will still be calling it the same.

articles.title: Florida's Irresponsible Refusal to Take Carbon Reduction Funding
articles.author: Sarah Martelly
articles.summary: Florida refused to accept $320 million in federal funding for the Carbon Reduction Program (CRP). Florida's average temperature has risen by 3.5°F since 1950. The state failed to submit a carbon reduction strategy. Broward County has only 320 public charging stations, meeting just 12% of demand.
